While Members of Congress can still submit legislation this way, they now have the additional option of submitting them digitally via "eHopper."

Congresswoman Angie Craig was the first to submit a bill to the eHopper in 2020!

Once a bill has been submitted to the hopper, which is attached to the Clerk's desk in the chamber, it is retrieved and referred to the appropriate committee.

But did you know that it wasn't until 2020 that another way to submit bills became available in the House?

Happy #FunFact Friday!

Can you guess what Congressman Maverick was doing in this photo snapped in 1937?

He was submitting a piece of legislation via bill hopper! For generations, this wooden box was the only way Members of Congress submitted legislation to the House. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNBThK7WUAQ1a8a.jpg

We finally made some progress yesterday, passing the Honoring our PACT Act I've been working hard on to ensure veterans impacted by burn pits get better health care and benefits from the VA. I'm happy we got this passed, but this is part of a larger problem in America. (4/6)

Wes used his pain and suffering to help others. He was a hero. The VA has denied about 80% of claims related to burn pits, so Wes spread awareness to get more vets exposed real care. His actions will save lives. (3/6)

The military uses massive burn pits to eliminate waste, but they release toxic fumes right next to where soldiers are stationed all day. When Wes returned from duty, he told his VA doctors about troubling symptoms. No provider connected it to burn pits until it was too late.(2/6)

Democrats and Republicans need to lock arms and say: "As we sanction Russian oil, we must increase oil & gas production in the short run (including by pressuring the Saudis). But there will still be sacrifice at home, and we agree freedom and security are worth the price." 9/

Back to politics: many Republicans privately admit we can't "replace" all the Russian oil, but they want Biden to ban it all anyway, and then criticize him for the inevitable increase in gas prices.

We can't afford that kind of cynical partisanship right now. 8/

If you want to shield American gas consumers from the impact of Russia's war, your problem is not Biden; it's Saudi Crown Prince MBS. This supposed US ally could produce more oil today but refuses, to protect a production agreement he made with Putin! 7/ https://www.wilsoncenter.org/article/saudi-arabia-chooses-putin-over-biden-ukraine-keep-oil-prices-high

If on top of all that, you also want to drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, know that it wouldn't produce oil till 2031. The Keystone Pipeline also would take years to come online.

These projects would have no impact on gas prices today. 6/ https://www.eia.gov/outlooks/aeo/anwr.php

Meanwhile, Biden is approving oil and gas drilling permits on public lands at a faster rate than Trump, and has been criticized for it by environmental groups. 5/

Republicans have been arguing that we could make up for losing Russian energy by stopping "Biden's war on oil" at home. 

Huh?

In fact, there are 248 more active oil and gas rigs in the US today than when Biden took office, a 62% increase. 4/ https://rigcount.bakerhughes.com/

If we really wanted to deny Putin oil revenue, we'd try to stop all his oil and gas exports, not just the puny ones to the U.S.

But Russia is the world's #2 oil exporter -- second only to Saudi Arabia. Taking all that oil off the market overnight would explode gas prices. 3/

Last year, the US bought $17 billion worth of oil from Russia. That's not a huge number, and many US refiners are already ending their purchases anyway.

In comparison, Biden's sanctions cost Russian energy companies over $190 billion just this week. 2/ https://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Russian-Oil-Gas-Giants-Lose-95-of-Their-Market-Cap-On-London-Exchange.html

Of course we should stop buying Russian oil.

But please stop pretending this is a silver bullet, or that we could somehow "replace" all the Russian oil by drilling in America.
